title: Three-Dimensional Imaging of Buried Interfaces in Twisted Hexagonal Boron Nitride
content: The development of twisted van der Waals (vdW) heterostructures, where individual layers of 2D materials are successively stacked at relative rotation angles, has led to exciting applications in optoelectronics, sensing, energy storage, quantum computing and more [1]. Visualizing individual defect sites using atomic-resolution scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) could provide great insight into the structure-property relationships of quantum materials, particularly at vdW heterointerfaces. However, while STEM enables sub-Ã…ngstrom resolution imaging in two dimensions, it remains a major challenge to determine the three-dimensional locations of point defects at the buried interfaces of twisted 2D heterostructures. Firstly, the light-element composition of many vdW heterostructures is limited by poor imaging sensitivity of existing techniques such as annular dark-field (ADF-) STEM. Furthermore, probing these vertical interfaces requires high resolution parallel to the electron beam, which is currently limited by poor axial depth resolution limits (5-10 nm) and strict alignment requirements of electron tomography.
